Gordon,

Thanks Gordon.  Eliminating the threads crashing is an improvement.

On 3/7/2012 9:05 PM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
> This shows useful new info, thanks.
>
> Some observations:
>
> � that the multiple retries don't help rules out some sorts of momentary
> inconsistency in the underlying BDBJE database. (The retry loop is there
> from a long-ago, long-fixed issue like that.)
>
> � that each of the affected queues reports '3' as their currentSize
> (when in fact there's nothing in them) suggests this isn't a matter of
> some single URI being misplaced (for example via some extremely rare
> timing/threading bug) but rather some common trigger/bug that affects
> several URIs together (and perhaps the usual 'triple' of
> rootpage-robots-DNS that wind up being queued for even an unresolvable
> domain).
>
> � I'm not sure if the fact they're all 'z' domains might be relevant (in
> some weird way) or this is just be an artifact of how you've split up
> your crawl.
>
Other instances have had these problems where the domains had non-z domains.

See the log from instance #4 of our crawl...

> That the threads no longer die is surely an improvement, but there's
> still the possibility that ~3 URIs per affected queue have been
> overlooked, and/or that future URIs on the same queue might not be tried
> properly.
>
The logs from instance #4 show that the number of URIs could be much 
more than 3.

> When you looked for SEVERE "URI enqueueing failed" errors, did you (or
> could you) check *all* _out.logs/alert.logs that could have contributed
> to this crawl's state (any number of checkpoint-resumes ago)?
>
Yes.  The particular crawl job that I am using was running for about 10 
days straight without ever resuming from a checkpoint.

> If you have frontier-recover.logs, grepping them for all entries related
> to one of the affected domains might also shed some light as to what's
> actually happened.
>
I have attached a file with the results from grepping the frontier logs.

> - Gordon
>
> On 3/7/12 9:41 AM, David Pane wrote:
>> Thanks Gordon for you help. I had thought of making those changes but
>> was concerned about the consequences but was glad to hear they could be
>> made. Your expert advise is appreciate.
>>
>> I did have a few SEVERE errors previous to the point where I restarted
>> the crawler and got the thread crashes. (see attached document
>> SevereErrorsBeforeThreadCrashes.txt )
>>
>> I made the suggested changes and the attached file debug-output.txt has
>> the output with the errors. This change did eliminate the thread crashes.
>>
>> --David
>>
>> On 3/6/2012 7:07 PM, Gordon Mohr wrote:
>>> This is useful info, thanks.
>>>
>>> This tells us that where it's expecting a serialized CrawlURI, it's
>>> finding a zero-length entry instead. (So, 'exceeded' is somewhat
>>> misleading, there's too little data rather than too much.)
>>>
>>> There are intentional zero-length entries -- 'queue caps' -- under the
>>> keys that mark the beginning of each queue. What appears to be happening
>>> here is that even though there is an indication there should be an item
>>> in the queue (just after its 'cap'), there isn't.
>>>
>>> Thus the 'cap' for the lexicographically-next queue is being read
>>> instead. Notably, by the time your debugging info is logged, the
>>> 'headKey' value has been overwritten with the name of the next queue,
>>> rather than the one it was trying to read.
>>>
>>> WorkQueue.peek() is checking the local 'count' and should only be
>>> attempting the peekItem()/BdbMultipleWorkQueues.get() when there's
>>> something there (count> 0). So either the 'count' went wrong at some
>>> point, or an item that should be found went missing (or maybe was never
>>> successfully entered).
>>>
>>> Do you see any SEVERE "URI enqueueing failed" messages in your
>>> heritrix_out.log or alerts? (I see one path through
>>> BdbMultipleWorkQueues.put() where there might be the mistaken assumption
>>> that an insert has succeeded, incrementing the count, when it did not.
>>> While I'm not yet sure what could trigger such a case, it ought to
>>> create this sort of SEVERE message if it happens.)
>>>
>>> One small consolation is that it is likely the affected queue is either
>>> truly empty or should have had only a single URI, so the fact that it
>>> may be left by this error in a 'stuck' state may not have caused much
>>> (if any) content to be missed.
>>>
>>> A possible next step to collect more info would be to change where
>>> you've added your existing log-line, to instead check whether the result
>>> is zero-sized. IF SO, log what you're logging now, AND early-return
>>> null.
>>>
>>> That will likely trigger the retry-logic in BdbWorkQueue.peekItem, which
>>> at the very least will log more about the failure, but might also remedy
>>> or soften it to something that's recoverable without losing a thread.
>>>
>>> In particular, if you can trigger this error on demand from a certain
>>> place -- say it always happens soon after a checkpoint you have around
>>> is resumed -- the above small change might yield useful info right away.
>>>
>>> I've made a bug to track this issue:
>>>
>>> https://webarchive.jira.com/browse/HER-1996
>>>
>>> - Gordon
>>>
>>>

>>>>> death of

>>>>> suspect that 28 queues (hostnames) of URIs are no longer being

>>>>> info about what went wrong. Presumably whatever caused the topmost-URI

>>>>> data-on-disk changes, so those queues might continue to be inert even
>>>>> with some heroic tampering with heap state or the on-disk data.
>>>>>
>>>>> What would happen on an IA crawl would depend on the tradeoffs
>>>>> involved,
>>>>> but if there are errors suggesting data loss or skipping of intended
>>>>> collection content, usually those problems are investigated to
>>>>> resolution, occasional with catch-up or 'patch' crawling a bit
>>>>> later to
>>>>> fill known gaps.

>>>>> differently, and logged as WARNINGs rather than SEVERE, but probably

>>>>>>> queues. At
>>>>>>> the very least the URI in process will not be crawled; it is also
>>>>>>> likely
>>>>>>> the entire queue it came from is no longer in frontier rotation, and
>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>> crawl may not checkpoint/terminate clearly. (That's even if other
>>>>>>> threads still appear to be making progress... are they?)
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> If these errors all happened only *after* checkpoint-resumption, it
>>>>>>> might be possible to find the cause or a workaround, and then again
>>>>>>> resume (more successfully without errors). However, it's also
>>>>>>> possible
>>>>>>> that these are reflecting earlier latent corruption in the
>>>>>>> earlier-crawl/checkpointed data.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Are any of the instances showing the problem (2,4) the one that had
>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>> other hung-checkpoint problem? (Do you have any idea what had
>>>>>>> triggered
>>>>>>> the IO-exceptions that were correlated with those failed/hung
>>>>>>> checkpoints?)
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Did the SEVERE SerializationExceptions occur right after
>>>>>>> resumption, or
>>>>>>> did they happen over a longer period (perhaps with more occcurences
>>>>>>> since the initial report)?
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> If for one of the affected instances, you try another resume from
>>>>>>> the
>>>>>>> exact same checkpoint, do the exact same number of errors occur?
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> I vaguely recall seeing a similar error when first converting to the
>>>>>>> 'Kryo' serialization (for compactness and speed), but believe the
>>>>>>> error
>>>>>>> at that time was quickly fixed (and no JIRA issue mentions the same
>>>>>>> BufferUnderflowException root cause). Our 'KryoBinding' class
>>>>>>> creates an
>>>>>>> ObjectBuffer that's supposed to grow as large as necessary
>>>>>>> (max-size:
>>>>>>> Integer.MAX_VALUE), so it should never be too small (but might
>>>>>>> trigger
>>>>>>> another kind of failure if it were growing without practical limit).
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Do the affected instances (2,4) show any other alert/WARNING/SEVERE
>>>>>>> log
>>>>>>> output, before or after the checkpoint-resume cycle?
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> Have you made any customizations to CrawlURI or added/modified
>>>>>>> objects
>>>>>>> that might be stored inside a CrawlURI?
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> I don't really know what's happening, but if you have a
>>>>>>> well-preserved
>>>>>>> checkpoint which can be repeatedly resumed to reproduce the exact
>>>>>>> same
>>>>>>> flurry of errors, there's a chance more testing (including added
>>>>>>> logging
>>>>>>> code) can be done to figure out exactly what's going wrong. Whether
>>>>>>> it's
>>>>>>> fixable in your checkpoints, or only for future crawls, remains
>>>>>>> to be
>>>>>>> seen.
>>>>>>>
>>>>>>> - Gordon
